DOC.HEAD: Measles Deaths Most Since 1971
For release 6 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The measles explosion of 1989, involving unvaccinated preschoolers and schoolchildren whose shots didn't work, has been accompanied by the most measles deaths in 18 years, federal health officials said Thursday. Forty-two deaths from measles have been reported this year, said national Centers for Disease Control measles specialist Dr. William L. Atkinson. That's the largest death count since 90 in 1971, he noted. Nationwide, 14,714 measles cases were counted with two weeks left in the year, the CDC said in its weekly report. That's more than five times the 2,876 cases reported at this point a year ago. An analysis of measles cases in the first six months of this year shows 30 percent occurred in children under 5, who are too young to fall under school-vaccination laws. Fifty-one percent occurred among young people 5-19. In the wake of the new measles explosion, CDC researchers have recommended this year that children get vaccinated twice _ the initial dose at 15 months in most areas, then again at school entry, ages 4-6. In the first half of this year, 51 percent of measles cases occurred among people who were believed ``appropriately vaccinated,'' the Atlanta-based CDC said. The unvaccinated preschoolers present a separate problem, Atkinson noted. ``We've got to find some sort of clever ways to motivate parents to get their kids vaccinated,'' he said. ``A 15-month-old doesn't walk in on his own.'' Large measles outbreaks are continuing in Los Angeles, Chicago and Houston, primarily among young blacks and Hispanics, the CDC noted. Vaccination rates in some inner cities are as low as 49 percent in 2-year-olds, the agency said. Federal health officials believed measles eradication was within reach early in this decade; just 1,497 cases were reported in 1983. But the disease has bounced back, although still nowhere near the pre-vaccine levels of half a million cases a year. During 1971, when 90 patients died, 75,290 cases were reported.
